\documentclass[11pt]{article}

    % Basic figure setup, for now with no caption control since it's done
    % automatically by Pandoc (which extracts ![](path) syntax from Markdown).
    \usepackage{graphicx}
    % We will generate all images so they have a width \maxwidth. This means
    % that they will get their normal width if they fit onto the page, but
    % are scaled down if they would overflow the margins.
    \makeatletter
    \def\maxwidth{\ifdim\Gin@nat@width>\linewidth\linewidth
    \else\Gin@nat@width\fi}
    \makeatother
    \let\Oldincludegraphics\includegraphics
    % Set max figure width to be 80% of text width, for now hardcoded.
    \renewcommand{\includegraphics}[1]{\Oldincludegraphics[width=.8\maxwidth]{#1}}
    % Ensure that by default, figures have no caption (until we provide a
    % proper Figure object with a Caption API and a way to capture that
    % in the conversion process - todo).
    \usepackage{caption}
    \DeclareCaptionLabelFormat{nolabel}{}
    \captionsetup{labelformat=nolabel}

    \usepackage{adjustbox} % Used to constrain images to a maximum size 
    \usepackage{xcolor} % Allow colors to be defined

    \usepackage{geometry} % Used to adjust the document margins

    \AtBeginDocument{%
        \def\PYZsq{\textquotesingle}% Upright quotes in Pygmentized code
    }
    \usepackage{upquote} % Upright quotes for verbatim code
    \usepackage{eurosym} % defines \euro
    \usepackage[mathletters]{ucs} % Extended unicode (utf-8) support
    \usepackage[utf8x]{inputenc} % Allow utf-8 characters in the tex document

                                % normalem makes italics be italics, not underlines

    \newcommand{\OperatorTok}[1]{\textcolor[rgb]{0.40,0.40,0.40}{{#1}}}

\def\PY@reset{\let\PY@it=\relax \let\PY@bf=\relax%
    \let\PY@ul=\relax \let\PY@tc=\relax%
    \let\PY@bc=\relax \let\PY@ff=\relax}
\def\PY@tok#1{\csname PY@tok@#1\endcsname}
\def\PY@toks#1+{\ifx\relax#1\empty\else%
    \PY@tok{#1}\expandafter\PY@toks\fi}
\def\PY@do#1{\PY@bc{\PY@tc{\PY@ul{%
    \PY@it{\PY@bf{\PY@ff{#1}}}}}}}
\def\PY#1#2{\PY@reset\PY@toks#1+\relax+\PY@do{#2}}

    \begin{document}
    
    
    \maketitle
    
    

    
    \section[Iris Dataset ]{\texorpdfstring{Iris Dataset
\protect\includegraphics{data:image/jpeg;base64,}}{Iris Dataset Image of Iris}}\label{iris-dataset-image-of-iris}

\subsection{What is the Iris Dataset?}\label{what-is-the-iris-dataset}

\subsubsection{Introduction}\label{introduction}

The Iris Dataset, or also known as the Fisher's Iris Data set, is one of
the most widely used datasets to illustrate problems in multivaried
datasets, and can be used to demonstrate simple machine learning
techniques. The dataset is a record of measurements (petal lengths and
widths, sepal lengths and widths) of 3 different species of Iris
flowers, the Iris Sentosa, Iris virginica and Iris versicolor.

\subsubsection{Who created the Iris
Dataset?}\label{who-created-the-iris-dataset}

British statistician and biologist Ronald Fisher in his 1936 paper
\textbf{The use of multiple measurements in taxonomic problems as an
example of linear discriminant analysis.{[}1{]}} introduced this
dataset.

\subsubsection{Why is the Iris Dataset so
popular?}\label{why-is-the-iris-dataset-so-popular}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  It contains 150 observations, which is a mangeable size to deal with
  for machine learning, yet sufficient enough to provide accurate
  predictions.
\item
  The task of discriminating between the 3 species are simple but
  challenging due to overlaps between some of the measurements, even if
  they are a different species. This will be explained later.
\item
  The data is real and not made up.
\item
  The dataset has been published and been used by statisticians since
  Ronald Fisher wrote his paper in 1936.
\end{enumerate}

\subsubsection{Contents of Dataset}\label{contents-of-dataset}

We will now look at the contents of the Iris Dataset using pandas.
\textbf{Pandas{[}2{]}} is an open source library providing
high-performance, easy-to-use data structures and data analysis tools
for the Python programming language.

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}5}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} Import pandas.}
        \PY{k+kn}{import} \PY{n+nn}{pandas} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n+nn}{pd}
        
        \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} Load the iris data set from a URL.}
        \PY{n}{df} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{pd}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{read\PYZus{}csv}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s2}{\PYZdq{}}\PY{l+s+s2}{https://raw.githubusercontent.com/uiuc\PYZhy{}cse/data\PYZhy{}fa14/gh\PYZhy{}pages/data/iris.csv}\PY{l+s+s2}{\PYZdq{}}\PY{p}{)}
        
        \PY{n}{df} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} print dataset}
\end{Verbatim}


\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{outcolor}Out[{\color{outcolor}5}]:}      sepal\_length  sepal\_width  petal\_length  petal\_width    species

        1             4.9          3.0           1.4          0.2     setosa

        10            5.4          3.7           1.5          0.2     setosa

        13            4.3          3.0           1.1          0.1     setosa

        15            5.7          4.4           1.5          0.4     setosa
        16            5.4          3.9           1.3          0.4     setosa

        18            5.7          3.8           1.7          0.3     setosa
        19            5.1          3.8           1.5          0.3     setosa
        20            5.4          3.4           1.7          0.2     setosa
        21            5.1          3.7           1.5          0.4     setosa
        22            4.6          3.6           1.0          0.2     setosa
        23            5.1          3.3           1.7          0.5     setosa
        24            4.8          3.4           1.9          0.2     setosa
        25            5.0          3.0           1.6          0.2     setosa
        26            5.0          3.4           1.6          0.4     setosa
        27            5.2          3.5           1.5          0.2     setosa
        28            5.2          3.4           1.4          0.2     setosa
        29            4.7          3.2           1.6          0.2     setosa
        ..            {\ldots}          {\ldots}           {\ldots}          {\ldots}        {\ldots}
        120           6.9          3.2           5.7          2.3  virginica

        122           7.7          2.8           6.7          2.0  virginica
        123           6.3          2.7           4.9          1.8  virginica

        125           7.2          3.2           6.0          1.8  virginica

        128           6.4          2.8           5.6          2.1  virginica
        129           7.2          3.0           5.8          1.6  virginica

        131           7.9          3.8           6.4          2.0  virginica
        132           6.4          2.8           5.6          2.2  virginica
        133           6.3          2.8           5.1          1.5  virginica
        134           6.1          2.6           5.6          1.4  virginica
        135           7.7          3.0           6.1          2.3  virginica
        136           6.3          3.4           5.6          2.4  virginica
        137           6.4          3.1           5.5          1.8  virginica
        138           6.0          3.0           4.8          1.8  virginica
        139           6.9          3.1           5.4          2.1  virginica
        140           6.7          3.1           5.6          2.4  virginica
        141           6.9          3.1           5.1          2.3  virginica
        142           5.8          2.7           5.1          1.9  virginica
        143           6.8          3.2           5.9          2.3  virginica
        144           6.7          3.3           5.7          2.5  virginica
        145           6.7          3.0           5.2          2.3  virginica
        146           6.3          2.5           5.0          1.9  virginica
        147           6.5          3.0           5.2          2.0  virginica
        148           6.2          3.4           5.4          2.3  virginica
        149           5.9          3.0           5.1          1.8  virginica
        
        [150 rows x 5 columns]
\end{Verbatim}
            
    As we can see, the Iris Data set consists of 5 columns, and 150 rows of
data. The first 4 columns are the sepal length, sepal width, petal legth
and petal width (all measured in cm). The 5th column is the
classification of the iris species, basically its either the setosa,
versicolor or the virginica.

Let's take a closer look at the first row of the dataset:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}6}]:} \PY{n}{df}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{iloc}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}


\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{outcolor}Out[{\color{outcolor}6}]:} sepal\_length       5.1
        sepal\_width        3.5
        petal\_length       1.4
        petal\_width        0.2
        species         setosa
        Name: 0, dtype: object
\end{Verbatim}
            
    Here we can see that the first flower is a setosa flower, with its
measurements in cm.

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}7}]:} \PY{k+kn}{import} \PY{n+nn}{seaborn} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n+nn}{sns}
        
        
        \PY{n}{sns}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{pairplot}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{df}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{hue}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{species}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{outcolor}Out[{\color{outcolor}7}]:} <seaborn.axisgrid.PairGrid at 0x1d699c3f0b8>
\end{Verbatim}

    \adjustimage{max size={0.9\linewidth}{0.9\paperheight}}{output_5_1.png}
    \end{center}
